Crypto Book (Work in Progress)

Introduction

This book is an ongoing effort to gather some notes about cryptography with a focus on schemes which are relevant to the decentralized web such as multiparty signatures, zero-knowledge proofs, etc.

For now it consists of the following parts:

  • Mathematical Preliminaries:
  • Cryptographic Notions:
  • ZK Hack Puzzles Walk-through:

We assume that the reader has some basic knowledge of arithmetic and algebra and of common concepts from cryptography (hash functions, signatures, ...).

Here are a number of freely available textbooks to learn more (we will point to specific sections of them when needed):

  • A Computational Introduction to Number Theory and Algebra by Victor Shoup
  • the Boneh-Shoup cryptography textbook
  • lecture notes for an advanced graduate cryptography course by Jonathan Katz
  • The Joy of Cryptography by Mike Rosulek
  • Mathematics of Public Key Cryptography by Steven Galbraith
  • Least Authority's MoonMath manual
  • Proofs, Arguments, and Zero-Knowledge by Justin Thaler

Mathematical Notation

  • Given a set S, we let Sn denote the set of strings of length n over S, and S∗ the set of all strings, i.e., S∗=∪n≥0​Sn, where S0 denotes the singleton consisting of the empty string; the length of a string x is denoted ∣x∣.
  • Given a non-empty finite set S, the sampling of a variable s according to the uniform distribution is denoted s←$​S.
  • Unless specified otherwise, groups are denoted additively.

Basic Definitions

A binary operation over a set S is a function ⋆:S×S→S usually denoted in infix notation, meaning the image of (a,b)∈S×S is written a⋆b.

A group is a non-empty set G equipped with a binary operation ⋆ satisfying the following properties:

  • associativity: for every a,b,c∈G, (a⋆b)⋆c=a⋆(b⋆c);
  • identity element: there exists e∈G such that for every a∈G, e⋆a=a⋆e=a; e is called the identity element of G;
  • inverse element: for every a∈G, there exists b∈G such that a⋆b=b⋆a=e; b is called the inverse of a.

The use of determiner the for the identity element and the inverse of an element a is justified by the following proposition.

Proposition. Let G be a group. Then G has a unique identity element and every element a∈G has a unique inverse.

Proof. Assume that G has two identity elements e and e. Then e⋆e′=e (because e′ is an identity element) and e⋆e′=e′ (because e is an identity element), hence e=e′. Assume that some group element a has two inverses b and b′. Then b​=b⋆e=b⋆(a⋆b′)=(b⋆a)⋆b′=e⋆b′=b′.​

The group consisting of a single element e such that e⋆e=e is called the trivial group.

If the binary operation is commutative, i.e., for every a,b∈G, a⋆b=b⋆a, then G is said to be abelian.

If G is finite, the number of elements of G is called the order of G and denoted ∣G∣. If G is infinite, G is said to have infinite order.

Additive/Multiplicative Notation

There are two standard notation types for the group operation:

  • additive: the group operation is denoted +, the identity element is denoted 0, and the inverse of a is denoted −a; moreover, for k∈Z and a∈G, one defines ka:=⎩⎨⎧​0k termsa+⋯+a​​−((−k)a)​if k=0if k>0if k<0;​
  • multiplicative: the group operation is denoted ∗ or ⋅, the identity element is denoted 1, and the inverse of a is denote a−1; moreover, for k∈Z and a∈G, one defines ak:=⎩⎨⎧​1k termsa∗⋯∗a​​(a−k)−1​if k=0if k>0if k<0.​

In the case of multiplicative notation, the operation symbol might be omitted and the group law simply denoted by juxtaposition. By convention, for an "abstract" group, additive notation is restricted to abelian groups (meaning multiplicative notation is used either when the group is known to be non-abelian, or when the abelian/non-abelian character of the group is unspecified).

For the rest of this chapter, unless specified otherwise, the group operation will be denoted multiplicatively but the identity element will be denoted e for clarity.

Direct Product

Let (G,⋆) and (H,∙) be two groups. The direct product of G and H is the Cartesian product G×H:={(a,b)∣a∈G,b∈H} equipped with the binary operation ⋄ defined component-wise: (a,b)⋄(c,d)=(a⋆c,b∙d).

Proposition. The direct product as defined above is a group. Its identity element is (eG​,eH​), where eG​ and eH​ are respectively the identity element of G and H. The inverse of (a,b)∈G×H is (a−1,b−1).

For abelian groups, the direct product is sometimes called direct sum and denoted G⊕H.1

Subgroups

Let G be a group and H be a non-empty subset of G. The subset H is a subgroup of G if H equipped with the binary operation of G is a group.

Proposition. Let G be a group and H be subset of G. Then H is a subgroup of G if and only if (i) e∈H, (ii) for every a,b∈H, ab∈H, and (iii) for every a∈H, a−1∈H.

The following proposition gives a slightly more compact subgroup criterion.

Proposition. Let G be a group and H be subset of G. Then H is a subgroup of G if and only if e∈H and for every a,b∈H, ab−1∈H.

A subgroup of G is said to be proper if it is different from G. Any non-trivial group has at least one proper subgroup, namely {e}, called the trivial subgroup.

Proposition. The intersection of a (finite or infinite) set of subgroups is a subgroup.

Proof. Let H=∩i∈I​Hi​ be the intersection of a collection of subgroups Hi​, i∈I. Then, by the previous proposition, e∈Hi​ for every i∈I and hence e∈H. Let a,b∈H. Then, for every i∈I, a,b∈Hi​ and hence ab−1∈Hi​ again by the previous proposition. Thus, ab−1∈H. It follows that H is a subgroup.

Cosets and Lagrange Theorem

Let H be a subgroup of a group G. Consider the relation defined by a∼b if and only if ab−1∈H and the dual one defined by a∼b if and only if b−1a∈H. The following proposition show that these are equivalence relations.

Proposition. Let G be a group. Let H be a subgroup of G. Then the relation defined by a∼b if and only if ab−1∈H is an equivalence relation. The proposition also holds by replacing ab−1∈H by b−1a∈H.

Proof. Let H be a subgroup of G and ∼ be relation defined by a∼b if and only if ab−1∈H. Let us show that ∼ is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

  • reflexivity: e∈H implies that for every a∈G, aa−1∈H and hence a∼a;
  • symmetry: H being closed under under inverses implies that for every a,b∈G, a∼b​⇒ab−1∈H⇒(ab−1)−1∈H⇒ba−1∈H⇒b∼a;​
  • transitivity: H being closed under the binary operation implies that for every a,b,c∈G, (a∼b)∧(b∼c)​⇒(ab−1∈H)∧(bc−1∈H)⇒ab−1bc−1∈H⇒ac−1∈H⇒a∼c.​ The proof is similar for the relation defined by b−1a∈H.

Let H be a subgroup of G and ∼ be the equivalence relation a∼b⇔ab−1∈H. An equivalence class for ∼ is called a right coset of H. Being equivalence classes, right cosets form a partition of G. For g∈G, the right coset to which g belongs is easily seen to be Hg:={hg∣h∈H}. Similarly, an equivalence class for the relation relation a∼b⇔b−1a∈H is called a left coset of H. Left cosets form a partition of G and for g∈G, the left coset to which g belongs is gH:={gh∣h∈H}.

When G is abelian, the set of right cosets and the set of left cosets are the same, but when G is non-abelian this is not necessarily the case. Note that H itself is both a right and a left coset.

A cornerstone of group theory is Lagrange's theorem, which essentially follows from the fact that right cosets (as well as left cosets) all have the same size.

Lagrange's Theorem. Let G be a finite group. Then the order of any subgroup H of G divides the order of G.

Proof. Let H be a subgroup of G. For every g∈G, the mapping h↦hg is a bijection from H to the right coset Hg: it is obviously surjective and hg=h′g⇒hgg−1=h′gg−1⇒h=h′, hence it is injective. Hence, all right cosets have ∣H∣ elements. Since right cosets form a partition of G, we have ∣G∣=n∣H∣ where n is the number of right cosets.

A similar reasoning with left cosets shows that the number of left cosets is equal to the number of right cosets.

The number of right (or left) cosets of H is called the index of H in G and denoted [G:H]. Hence, Lagrange theorem states that ∣G∣=[G:H]∣H∣.

Normal Subgroups and Quotient Groups

Having defined an equivalence relation associated with a subgroup, one may ask whether the set of right (or left) cosets can be equipped with a group structure. This is where the notion of normal subgroup comes into play.

Let G be a group. A subgroup H of G is said to be normal if for every g∈G, gH=Hg (i.e., left and right cosets are equal).

Normality can be characterized by a number of other equivalent conditions. The easiest to check is often the following one.

Proposition. A subgroup H of G is normal if and only if for every g∈G, gHg−1⊆H.

For abelian groups, the situation is pretty simple.

Proposition. Every subgroup of an abelian group is normal.

Proof. If G is abelian and H is a subgroup of G, then for any h∈H, ghg−1=gg−1h=h and hence gHg−1=H. By the previous proposition, this implies that H is normal.

Let G be a group and let ∼ be an equivalence relation on G. We say that ∼ is compatible with the group structure of G if a∼b and c∼d implies ac∼bd. If ∼ is compatible with the group structure of G, then one can equip the quotient set G/∼ (the set of all equivalence classes) with a binary operation defined as [a][b]=[ab], where [a] denotes the equivalence class of a∈G. This is well defined as compatibility of ∼ with the group structure ensures that this binary operation does not depend on the specific representatives a and b of each equivalence class. The following proposition states that normal subgroups completely characterize the equivalence relations ∼ which are compatible with the group structure of G.

Proposition. Let G be a group and H be a normal subgroup of G. Then the equivalence relation defined by a∼b⇔ab−1∈H is compatible with the group structure of G. Conversely, let ∼ be an equivalence relation compatible with the group structure of G. Then H:=[e] is a normal subgroup of G and a∼b⇔ab−1∈H.

Proof. Let H be a normal subgroup of G. Let us show that ∼ defined by a∼b⇔ab−1∈H (which is an equivalence relation by Proposition) is compatible with the group structure of G. Let a,b,c,d∈G such that a∼b and c∼d. We want to show that ac∼bd, i.e., ac(bd)−1∈ H. Note that ac(bd)−1=acd−1b−1=acd−1a−1ab−1. We have cd−1∈H because c∼d, which implies that g:=a(cd−1)a−1∈H because H is normal. We also have ab−1∈H because a∼b, hence g(ab−1)=acd−1a−1ab−1=ac(bd)−1∈H and ac∼bd.

Conversely, assume that ∼ is an equivalence relation which is compatible with the group structure of G. Define H as [e], the equivalence class of the identity element. Let us first show that H is a normal subgroup. Clearly, e∈H. Let a,b∈H, i.e., a∼e and b∼e. Then, by compatibility of ∼ with the group structure, we have a∼e​⇒ab−1∼eb−1⇒ab−1e∼b−1b⇒ab−1∼e.​​(b−1∼b−1)(e∼b)​ Hence ab−1∈H and by Proposition, H is a subgroup.

To show that H is normal, let us show that for every g∈G, gHg−1⊆H. Let g∈G and h∈H. Then h∼e​⇒gh∼g⇒ghg−1∼gg−1⇒ghg−1∼e.​​(g∼g)(g−1∼g−1)​ Hence ghg−1∈H and H is normal.

It remains to show a∼b⇔ab−1∈H. By compatibility of ∼ with the group structure, we have a∼b⇒ab−1∼bb−1⇒ab−1∼e and ab−1∼e⇒ab−1b∼b⇒a∼b. Hence a∼b⇔ab−1∼e⇔ab−1∈H, which concludes the proof.

Let H be a normal subgroup of G and let ∼ be the equivalence relation defined by a∼b⇔ab−1∈H. Then the quotient set G/∼ equipped with the binary operation defined by [a][b]=[ab] is a group (as shown in the proposition below) called the quotient group associated with H and denoted G/H. Note that the order of G/H is [G:H], the index of H.

Proposition. Let G be a group and H be a normal subgroup of G. Then G/H is a group. Its identity element is [e] and the inverse of [a] is [a]−1:=[a−1]. If G is abelian then so is G/H.

Proof. This follows straightforwardly from the definition of the binary operation [a][b]=[ab].

Homomorphisms and Isomorphisms

Let G and G′ be two groups. A group homomorphism is a function f from G to G′ such that for every a,b∈G, f(ab)=f(a)f(b). If f is bijective, then f is called a group isomorphism and groups G and G′ are said isomorphic, denoted G≅G′. If moreover G=G′, f is called a group automorphism.

Proposition. Let G and G′ be two groups and f:G→G′ be a group homomorphism. Then:

  • f(eG​)=eG′​,
  • for every a∈G, f(a−1)=f(a)−1,
  • for every subgroup H of G, f(H):={f(a)∣a∈H} is a subgroup of G′,
  • for every subgroup H′ of G′, f−1(H′):={a∈G∣f(a)∈H′} is a subgroup of G.

Let f:G→G′ be a group homomorphism. The kernel of f is the subset of G defined as ker(f):={a∈G∣f(a)=eG′​}. The image of f is the subset of G′ defined as im(f):={f(a)∣a∈G}.

By the previous proposition, ker(f) is a subgroup of G since it is equal to f−1({eG′​}) and im(f) is a subgroup of G′ since it is equal to f(G).

First Isomorphism Theorem. Let f:G→G′ be a group homomorphism. Then ker(f) is a normal subgroup of G and G/ker(f)≅im(f).

Proof. Let us first show that ker(f) is normal. Let g∈G and h∈ker(f). Then f(ghg−1)​=f(g)f(h)f(g−1)=f(g)eG′​f(g)−1=f(g)f(g)−1=eG′​.​ Hence gker(f)g−1⊆ker(f) and hence ker(f) is normal.

Consider now the mapping fˉ​:G/ker(f)→im(f) defined by fˉ​([a])=f(a). It is well-defined since [a]=[b]​⟺ab−1∈ker(f)⟺f(ab−1)=eG′​⟺f(a)=f(b).​ In other words, equivalence classes of G/ker(f) are just subsets of elements of G with the same image under f. Consequently, the definition of fˉ​ does not depend on the representative of the equivalence class.

It is a group homomorphism since fˉ​([a][b])​=fˉ​([ab])=f(ab)=f(a)f(b)=fˉ​([a])fˉ​([b]).​ Moreover, it is injective since fˉ​([a])=fˉ​([b])⇔f(a)=f(b)⇔[a]=[b]. It is also surjective since any element in h∈im(f) is of the form f(a) for some a∈G and hence h=fˉ​([a]). Hence, fˉ​ is a group isomorphism.

There are three other isomorphism theorems but they are not as useful as the first one.

Group Generation

Let G be a group and A be a subset of G. The subgroup generated by A, denoted ⟨A⟩, is the intersection of all subgroups of G containing A. (Recall that by Proposition, an intersection of subgroups is a subgroup.) Informally, it is the "smallest" (for inclusion) subgroup of G which contains A: any subgroup containing A contains ⟨A⟩.

The following proposition gives a more explicit characterization.

Proposition. Let G be a group and A be a subset of G. Then ⟨A⟩ is the subgroup of all elements of G that can be expressed as the finite product of elements of A and inverse of elements of A.

Note in particular that ⟨∅⟩={e} (in which case the previous proposition still holds with the convention that an empty product is equal to e).

If A={a1​,…,ak​} is finite, the subgroup generated by A is also denoted ⟨a1​,…,ak​⟩. When G is abelian, then ⟨a1​,…,ak​⟩={a1z1​​⋯akzk​​∣z1​,…,zk​∈Z}.

A group G is said to be finitely generated is there exists a finite number of elements g1​,…gk​∈G such that G=⟨g1​,…,gk​⟩, in which case {g1​,…,gk​} is called a generating set of G.

A group G is said cyclic (or monogenous2) if there exists g∈G such that G=⟨g⟩, in which case g is called a generator of G.

The order of an element a∈G is the order of the subgroup ⟨a⟩. If G has infinite order, the order of an element a∈G can be finite or infinite.

Below we list a number of properties of the order of an element.

Proposition. Let G be a group and a∈G be a group element. Then a has finite order if and only if there exists k∈N∗ such that ak=e. In that case, a's order is the smallest integer n≥1 such that an=e and one has ⟨a⟩={e,a,a2,…,an−1}.

Proposition. If G has finite order n, then the order of any element a∈G divides n. In particular, for any a∈G, an=e.

Proof. The first part is a direct consequence of Lagrange's theorem. For the second part, let m be the order of a and write n=dm. Then an=adm=(am)d=ed=e.

Proposition. Let G be a group and a∈G be an element of order n. Then for every k∈Z, ak=e if and only if n divides k.

Proof. If n divides k then k=dn for some integer d, which implies ak=adn=(an)d=ed=e. Conversely, assume that ak=e. By Euclid's division lemma, there exists q,r∈Z such that k=qn+r and 0≤r<n. Then ak=aqn+r=(an)qar=ar and consequently ar=e. This implies that r=0 as otherwise a would have order r<n. Hence, k=qn and n divides k.

Proposition. Let G be a group, a∈G be an element of order n, and k∈Z. Then the order of gk is n/gcd(n,k).

Proof. Let d=gcd(k,n) and let ℓ be the order of gk. Then (gk)ℓ=gkℓ=e and hence by Proposition, n∣kℓ, which implies (dn​)∣(dk​)ℓ. Since gcd(dn​,dk​)=1, this implies dn​∣ℓ.

On the other hand, (gk)dn​=(gn)dk​=edk​=e, and hence by Proposition, ℓ∣dn​. We conclude that ℓ=n/d.

Properties of Cyclic Groups

Proposition. Any cyclic group is abelian.

Proof. Let G be a cyclic group, let g be a generator of G, and let a,b∈G be two group elements. Then there exists k,ℓ∈Z such that a=gk and b=gℓ, which implies that ab=gkgℓ=gk+ℓ=gℓgk=ba.

Proposition. Let G be a cyclic group and H be a subgroup of G. Then H and G/H are cyclic.

Proof. Let G be a cyclic group, g be a generator of G, and H be a subgroup of G. Let us first show that H is cyclic. If H={e} then H is clearly cyclic. Otherwise, let n≥1 be the smallest integer such that gn∈H (which necessarily exists since H contains at least one element different from e and either this element or its inverse can be written gm for some m≥1). We will prove that H=⟨gn⟩. Clearly, ⟨gn⟩⊆H since H is a subgroup. Conversely, let a∈H. Then a=gk for some k∈Z. By Euclid's division lemma, there exists q,r∈Z such that k=qn+r and 0≤r<n. Then a=gk=gqn+r=(gn)qgr, and consequently gr∈H. This implies that r=0 as otherwise this would contradict the minimality of n. Hence a=(gn)q∈⟨gn⟩ and H⊆⟨gn⟩. Thus, H=⟨gn⟩ and hence H is cyclic.

Let us now show that G/H is cyclic. More precisely, let us prove that G/H=⟨[g]⟩. Let [a]∈G/H be an element of the quotient group specified by an arbitrary representative a∈G. Then there exists k∈Z such that a=gk. Thus, [a]=[gk]=[g]k and hence [g] is a generator of G/H.

Proposition. Any group with prime order is cyclic and any element different from the identity element is a generator of G.

Proof. Let G be a group of prime order p. Let a∈G be an element different from the identity element and let n be the order of a. Since the order of an element divides the order of the group by Proposition, one has either n=1 or n=p. Since a=e, one cannot have n=1, hence n=p and a generates G.

Proposition. Let G be a cyclic group of order n, g be a generator of G, and k∈Z. Then ⟨gk⟩=G if and only if gcd(n,k)=1. In particular, G has ϕ(n) generators, where ϕ is Euler's function.

Proof. We have ⟨gk⟩=G if and only if the order of gk is n, which by Proposition is equivalent to gcd(n,k)=1.

For the second part of the proposition, write G={e,g,…,gn−1}. Then generators of G are exactly elements of the form gk with gcd(n,k)=1 and hence there are ϕ(n) such elements.

Proposition. Let G1​ and G2​ be two cyclic groups of order n1​ and n2​ respectively. Then the direct product G1​×G2​ is cyclic if and only if gcd(n1​,n2​)=1. Moreover, (g1​,g2​) is a generator of G1​×G2​ if and only if g1​ is a generator of G1​ and g2​ is a generator of G2​.

Proof. Let us first show the following lemma: Let a1​∈G1​ be an element of order k1​ and a2​∈G2​ be an element of order k2​. Then (a1​,a2​) has order lcm(k1​,k2​).

Let e1​ be the identity element of G1​ and e2​ be the identity element of e2​. Then (a1​,a2​)k=(e1​,e2​)​⟺a1k​=e1​∧a2k​=e2​⟺k1​∣k∧k2​∣k.​ The smallest such positive integer k is by definition lcm(k1​,k2​), which proves the lemma.

Let us now prove the proposition. Assume that G1​×G2​ is cyclic and let (g1​,g2​) be a generator of G1​×G2​. Then clearly g1​ must be a generator of G1​ and g2​ a generator of G2​. By the previous lemma, (g1​,g2​) has order lcm(n1​,n2​). On the other hand, (g1​,g2​) has order ∣G1​×G2​∣=n1​n2​ as it generates G1​×G2​. Hence, lcm(n1​,n2​)=n1​n2​, which implies gcd(n1​,n2​)=1.

Conversely, assume that gcd(n1​,n2​)=1 and let g1​ be a generator of G1​ and g2​ be a generator of G2​. By the lemma, (g1​,g2​) has order lcm(n1​,n2​)=n1​n2​=∣G1​×G2​∣ and hence generates G1​×G2​.

Classification of Cyclic Groups

The set of integers Z={…,−2,−1,0,1,2,…} equipped with addition is a cyclic group of infinite order with identity element 0 and generators 1 and −1. For any integer n∈N, the set nZ:={nz∣z∈Z} is a subgroup of Z of infinite order. It is cyclic and generated by n and −n. These are in fact the only subgroups of Z.

Proposition. Let G be a subgroup of Z. Then there exists a unique n∈N such that G=nZ.

Proof. Le us show existence first. If G={0} then G=0Z. Assume now that G={0}, implying that G contains at least one positive integer (it contains at least one non-zero integer a and either a or −a is positive). Let n be the smallest positive integer in G. Let us show that G=nZ. Clearly, nZ⊆G since n∈G. Conversely, let k∈G. By Euclid's division lemma, there exists q,r∈Z such that k=qn+r and 0≤r<n. Since n and k are in G, r=k−qn is also in G, which implies r=0 as otherwise this would contradict the minimality of n. Thus, k=qn∈nZ and G⊆nZ. Hence, G=nZ which proves existence.

For uniqueness, assume that G=nZ=n′Z for n,n′∈N. Then n∈n′Z implies n′∣n and n′∈nZ implies n∣n′, and consequently n=n′ since n and n′ are in N.

For any n∈N, we can consider the quotient group Z/nZ. The equivalence class of a∈Z is [a]={a+nz∣z∈Z}, also called the residue class of a modulo n. There are n distinct classes. Hence, the index of nZ is n and Z/nZ has order n. It is cyclic with generator [1] (and [−1]). More generally, by Proposition, the generators of Z/nZ are [k] for k∈Z such that gcd(k,n)=1.

Another way to think of Z/nZ is as the set {0,1,…,n−1} equipped with "modulo n" addition and inverses. More precisely, let Zn​ be the set of symbols {[[0]],[[1]],…,[[n−1]]} equipped with the binary operation [[a]]+[[b]]=[[(a+b)modn]]. This is a group with identity [[0]] and inverse −[[a]]=[[(−a)modn]]. One can easily see that Z/nZ and Zn​ are isomorphic, the isomorphism being [a]↦[[amodn]]. From now on, we will work with the latter formalism.

For any integer m∈Z, mZn​:={m[[u]]∣[[u]]∈Zn​} is a subgroup of Zn​. What does this subgroup look like? One has [[a]]∈mZn​​⇔∃[[u]]∈Zn​,[[a]]=m[[u]]⇔∃u∈{0,1,…,n−1},a=mumodn⇔∃u∈Z,a=mumodn⇔∃u,v∈Z,a=um+vn⇔gcd(m,n)∣a​(by Beˊzout’s lemma).​ Hence, letting d=gcd(m,n), we see that mZn​ is the subset of Zn​ containing multiples of d, i.e., mZn​={[[kd]]∣k=0,…,n/d−1}=dZn​. In particular, mZn​ has order n/d and index d. (As we will see shorty, mZn​ being cyclic, one has mZn​≅Zn/d​.)

Again, we can show that these are in fact the only subgroups of Zn​.

Proposition. Let n∈N and G be a subgroup of Zn​. Then there is a unique d∈N such that d∣n and G=dZn​.

Proof. Let G be a subgroup of Zn​. Let us prove existence first. Let H:={a+kn∣[[a]]∈G,k∈Z}. Then H is a subgroup of Z: it is clearly non-empty and for b,b′∈H, b=a+kn and b′=a′+k′n, one has b−b′​=(a−a′)+(k−k′)n=(a−a′modn)+k′′n​for some k′′∈Z,​ hence b−b′∈H. Thus, there exists d∈N such that H=dZ. Moreover, since 0∈G, n∈H and hence d∣n. Since G={[[a]]∣a∈H∩{0,…,n−1}}, it follows that G=dZn​.

Let us now prove uniqueness. Assume that G=dZn​=d′Zn​ for d,d′∈N with d and d′ dividing n. Since [[d]]∈dZn​, this implies [[d]]∈d′Zn​={[[kd′]]∣k=0,…,n/d′−1} and hence d′∣d. Conversely, d∣d′ and hence d=d′ since d and d′ are in N.

We can now prove the following two "structure theorems" stating that, up to isomorphism, Z and Zn​ are the only cyclic groups of infinite, resp. finite order n.

Fundamental Theorem of Cyclic Groups, Infinite Order. Let G be a cyclic group of infinite order. Then G is isomorphic to Z and the subgroups of G are exactly the subsets Gn:={an∣a∈G} for n∈N.

Fundamental Theorem of Cyclic Groups, Finite Order. Let G be a cyclic group of order n. Then G is isomorphic to Zn​ and the subgroups of G are exactly the subsets Gd:={ad∣a∈G} for d∈N such that d∣n. In particular, G has exactly one subgroup of order d for each divisor d of n, namely Gn/d.

Proof. Let G be a cyclic group and g be a generator of G. Consider the mapping f:Z→G defined by f(k)=gk. Then f is a group homomorphism since f(k+ℓ)=gk+ℓ=gkgℓ=f(k)f(ℓ). It is clearly surjective since g is a generator of G.

Consider first the case where G has infinite order. Let us show that f is injective. Assume that f(k)=f(ℓ) for distinct integers k and ℓ with k<ℓ. Then f(ℓ−k)=gℓ−k=e, contradicting the fact that g has infinite order. Hence, f is an isomorphism form Z to G. Since the subgroups of Z are exactly nZ for n∈N, the subgroups of G are exactly f(nZ)​={gk∣k∈nZ}={gkn∣k∈Z}={an∣a∈G},​ where the last equality follows from g being a generator and hence G={gk∣k∈Z}.

Consider now the case where G has finite order n. Let us show that ker(f)=nZ. Since g has order n, by Proposition, for every k∈Z, gk=e⇔k∣n, which exactly means that k∈ker(f)⇔k∈nZ. Hence, ker(f)=nZ. By the first isomorphism theorem, im(f)=G≅Z/nZ≅Zn​.

Let fˉ​:Zn​→G be the isomorphism defined by fˉ​([[k]])=gk. Since the subgroups of Zn​ are exactly dZn​ for d∈N such that d∣n, the subgroups of G are exactly fˉ​(dZn​)​={gk∣[[k]]∈dZn​}={gkd∣k=0,…,n−1}={ad∣a∈G}.​

Cauchy's Theorem for Abelian Groups

Lagrange's theorem states that the order of a subgroup of a finite group divides the order of the group. Conversely, given a divisor d of the order of the group, does there always exist a subgroup of order d? A group where this property holds is called a converse Lagrange theorem (CLT) group. The answer is no in general. However, there are specific cases where the existence of a subgroup is guaranteed. Cauchy's theorem states that for every group G (non-necessarily abelian) of finite order and every prime divisor p of ∣G∣, G has a subgroup of order p. Cauchy's theorem is a special case of Sylow's (first) theorem.

Here, we will only prove it in the easier case where G is abelian. Actually, a more general result (that will follow easily from the fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups) is that any finite abelian group is CLT. In other words, for a finite abelian group of order n, the existence of a subgroup of order d is guaranteed for any divisor d of n, not only for prime divisors.

Cauchy's Theorem (Abelian Case). Let G be an abelian group of finite order n. Then, for every prime divisor p of n, there exists a subgroup of G of order p (or, equivalently, there exists an element of G of order p).

Proof. The equivalence between the two conclusions follows from the fact that a group of prime order is necessarily cyclic.

Let {a1​,…,ar​} be a generating set of G and for i∈{1,…,r} let ni​ denote the order of ai​. Consider the mapping f:⟨a1​⟩×⋯×⟨ar​⟩→G defined by f(x1​,…,xr​)=x1​⋯xr​. Since G is abelian, it is a group homomorphism. Moreover, since {a1​,…,ar​} is a generating set, f is surjective (indeed, by definition of a generating set of an abelian group, any element y∈G can be written as y=a1k1​​⋯arkr​​ for some integers k1​,…,kr​∈Z and for each i∈{1,…,r}, aiki​​∈⟨ai​⟩). By the first isomorphism theorem, G is isomorphic to (⟨a1​⟩×⋯×⟨ar​⟩)/ker(f), which implies that ∣G∣⋅∣ker(f)∣​=∣⟨a1​⟩×⋯×⟨ar​⟩∣=n1​⋯nr​,​ and hence n=∣G∣ divides n1​⋯nr​.

Let p be a prime divisor of n. Then p divides n1​⋯nr​ and hence p divides ni​ for some i∈{1,…,r}. Then we can write ni​=kp and by Proposition, aik​ has order ni​/gcd(ni​,k)=ni​/k=p, which concludes the proof.

Exponent of a Group

Let G be a group. Consider the subset of Z defined as {k∈Z∣∀a∈G,ak=e}. One can easily check that this is a subgroup of Z. Hence, by Proposition, there is a unique integer m∈N such that this subgroup is equal to mZ. This integer m is called the exponent of G. Equivalently, it is defined as the smallest positive integer m≥1 such that ∀g∈G, gm=e. If no such integer exists, depending on the convention, G is said to have exponent 0 or infinite exponent. A finite group of order n necessarily has finite exponent m satisfying m∣n (since by Proposition, an=e for every a∈G and hence n∈mZ). Moreover, the order of any group element divides m by Proposition. Conversely, a group with infinite exponent necessarily has infinite order. However, a group with finite exponent is not necessarily finite.

In the following, we prove that an abelian group or finite exponent m always contains a element of order m. This will be a key lemma for proving the fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups. Note that none of the three following propositions holds for a non-abelian group.

Proposition. Let G be an abelian group and a1​ and a2​ be two elements of respective order n1​ and n2​ such that gcd(n1​,n2​)=1. Then the order of a1​a2​ is n1​n2​. More generally, if a1​,…,ar​ are r group elements of respective orders n1​,…,nr​ such that gcd(n1​,…,nr​)=1, then the order of a1​⋯ar​ is n1​⋯nr​.

Proof. Let n be the order of a1​a2​. Since (a1​a2​)n1​n2​=(a1n1​​)n2​(a2n2​​)n1​=e, by Proposition, we have n∣n1​n2​.

On the other hand, since (a1​a2​)n=e, one has a1n​=a2−n​ and hence a1n​∈⟨a2​⟩. This implies that (a1n​)n2​=a1nn2​​=e, hence n1​∣nn2​. But since gcd(n1​,n2​)=1, n1​∣n. Symmetrically, one also has n2​∣n. Since gcd(n1​,n2​)=1, this implies n1​n2​∣n and hence n=n1​n2​. The generalization can be proved by induction on r.

Proposition. Let G be an abelian group and a1​ and a2​ be two elements of respective order n1​ and n2​. Then there exists an element of G of order lcm(n1​,n2​).

Proof. Let p1e1​​⋯prer​​ be the prime factor decomposition of lcm(n1​,n2​). For each i∈{1,…,r}, piri​​ divides either n1​ or n2​. Say it divides n1​ (the reasoning is similar if it divides n2​). Then, by Proposition, a1n1​/piri​​​ has order n1​/gcd(n1​,n1​/piri​​)=piri​​. Hence, for each i∈{1,…,r}, there exists an element bi​ of order piri​​. By Proposition, b1​⋯br​ has order p1e1​​⋯prer​​=lcm(n1​,n2​).

Proposition. Let G be an abelian group of finite exponent m. Then there exists an element of G of order m.

Proof. By Proposition, the order of any group element divides m. In particular, all group elements have order at most m and hence there exists a group element of maximal order m′≤m. Assume towards a contradiction that m′<m. If the order of every group element divides m′, then for every a∈G, am′=e, contradicting the minimality of m. Otherwise, assume that there is a group element of order m′′ which does not divide m′. Then, by Proposition, there exists an element of order lcm(m′,m′′)>m′ contradicting the maximality of m′. Hence, it must be that m=m′, which concludes the proof.

As a direct corollary, we have that a finite abelian group is cyclic if and only if its order is equal to its exponent.

Structure Theorem for Finite Abelian Groups

This section presents the fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups, sometimes called Kronecker theorem. As we will see, finite abelian groups can be "decomposed" in two ways. The equivalence between these two decompositions relies on the following theorem.

Chinese Remainder Theorem for Groups. Let n1​ and n2​ be two positive integers. Then Zn1​​×Zn2​​≅Zn1​n2​​ if and only if gcd(n1​,n2​)=1.

Proof. Assume that gcd(n1​,n2​)=1. Consider the mapping f:Z→Zn1​​×Zn2​​ defined by f(z)=(zmodn1​,zmodn2​). One can easily check that f is a group homomorphism. Moreover, z∈ker(f)⇔(n1​∣z)∧(n2​∣z)⇔n1​n2​∣z, where the last equivalence follows from gcd(n1​,n2​)=1. Hence, ker(f)=n1​n2​Z. By the first isomorphism theorem, Zn1​n2​​≅Z/n1​n2​Z is isomorphic to im(f). In particular, ∣im(f)∣=∣Zn1​n2​​∣=n1​n2​=∣Zn1​​×Zn2​​∣, hence im(f)=Zn1​​×Zn2​​. Thus, Zn1​n2​​≅Zn1​​×Zn2​​.

Conversely, assume that gcd(n1​,n2​)=d>1. By Proposition, Zn1​​×Zn2​​ is not cyclic. As Zn1​n2​​ is cyclic, these two groups cannot be isomorphic.

Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups. Let G be a non-trivial finite abelian group. Then:

  • (primary decomposition): G is isomorphic to a direct product of cyclic groups Zp1r1​​​×⋯×Zptrt​​​, where the pi​'s are (not necessarily distinct) primes and the ri​'s are positive integers. This decomposition is unique up to the order of factors. The prime powers p1r1​​,…,ptrt​​ are called the elementary divisors of G.
  • (invariant factor decomposition): G is isomorphic to a direct product of cyclic groups Zn1​​×⋯×Znℓ​​, where the ni​'s are positive integers such that for i=1,…,ℓ−1, ni​∣ni+1​. This decomposition is unique and nℓ​ is the exponent of the group. The integers n1​,…,nℓ​ are called the invariant factors of G.

Proof. TODO

Consider for example Z6​×Z15​. What are the primary and invariant factor decompositions of this group? By the Chinese remainder theorem, we have Z6​×Z15​​=Z2×3​×Z3×5​≅Z2​×Z3​×Z3​×Z5​≅Z3​×Z30​.​ The penultimate form is the primary decomposition, while the last form is the invariant factor decomposition.

The smallest abelian non-cyclic group is Z2​×Z2​ of order 4, usually called the Klein group.

Proposition. A finite abelian group is cyclic if and only if ℓ=1 in its invariant factor decomposition.

For an integer n, one may ask how many different abelian groups of order n there are, up to isomorphism. Let π denote the partition function defined as follows: for an integer n, π(n) is the number of distinct ways of writing n as a sum of positive integers, where the order of these integers does not matter. For example, π(3)=3 since 3 has 3 partitions: 1+1+1, 1+2, and 3.

Number of Finite Abelian Groups of Order n. Let n≥1 be an integer and let its decomposition in prime factors be n=p1r1​​⋯pkrk​​. Then the number of abelian groups of order n, up to isomorphism, is π(r1​)⋯π(rk​), where π is the partition function. In particular, there is a unique abelian group of order n up to isomorphism (namely Zn​) if and only if n is square-free, i.e., r1​=⋯=rk​=1.

For example, there is a unique (up to isomorphism) abelian group of order 15=3×5, namely Z3​×Z5​≅Z15​ (primary/invariant factor decomposition). On the other hand, there are two (up to isomorphism) abelian groups of order 12=22×3, namely Z4​×Z3​≅Z12​ and Z2​×Z2​×Z3​≅Z2​×Z6​.

Structure Theorem for Finitely Generated Abelian Groups

We now consider abelian groups which are finitely generated (but not necessarily of finite order).

Let G be an abelian group. For n∈N∗, an element a∈G is said to be an n-torsion element if an=e (or equivalently, if a has finite order k dividing n). An element a∈G is said to be a torsion element if it has finite order.

Proposition. Let G be an abelian group. Then the set of all n-torsion elements of G, denoted G[n], is a subgroup called the n-torsion subgroup of G and the set of all torsion elements of G, denoted GT​, is a subgroup called the torsion subgroup of G.

Proof. Since e is clearly an n-torsion element, G[n] is non-empty. Let a and b be two n-torsion elements. Then (ab−1)n=an(bn)−1=ee−1=e, hence ab−1 is an n-torsion element. Hence G[n] is a subgroup of G.

Similarly, e is a torsion element, hence GT​ is non-empty. Let a and b be two torsion elements of order respectively k and ℓ. Then (ab−1)kℓ=akℓ(bℓk)−1=eℓ(ek)−1=e. Hence ab−1 has finite order, i.e., it is a torsion element. Hence GT​ is a subgroup of G.

If G=GT​ then G is called a torsion group (or periodic group). If G={0} then G is said torsion-free.

Fundamental Theorem of Finitely Generated Abelian Groups. Let G be a finitely generated abelian group. Let GT​ be the torsion subgroup of G. Then GT​ is finite and abelian and there exists a free abelian subgroup F such that G=F×GT​. In particular, there exists a integer r∈N (called the free rank or simply rank of G) and integers n1​,…,nℓ​ with n1​∣⋯∣nℓ​ such that G≅Zr×Zn1​​×⋯×Znℓ​​. Integers r and n1​,…,nℓ​ are unique.

Polynomials

Generalities

Let F be a field (not necessarily finite). A (univariate) polynomial with coefficients in F is an infinite sequence (ai​)i∈N​ such that ai​=0 for all but a finite number of indices i. Polynomials are traditionally denoted p(X)=a0​+a1​X+a2​X2+⋯=i=0∑∞​ai​Xi where X is a symbol called indeterminate.

The set of all univariate polynomials over F is denoted F[X]: F[X]:={i=0∑∞​ai​Xi:ai​∈F,∃N∈N,∀i≥N,ai​=0}.

Polynomials can be added: i=0∑∞​ai​Xi+i=0∑∞​bi​Xi=i=0∑∞​(ai​+bi​)Xi.

Polynomials can also be multiplied: i=0∑∞​ai​Xi⋅j=0∑∞​bj​Xj=k=0∑∞​ck​Xkwithck​=i+j=k∑​ai​bj​.

The set F[X] equipped with operations + and ⋅ is a ring called the polynomial ring in X over F. Moreover, if we define scalar multiplication of a polynomial p(X) by a∈F as multiplication by the constant polynomial a(X)=a, then F[X] is a vector space over F. The set {1,X,X2,…} is a basis of this vector space called the monomial basis.

The degree of a polynomial p(X) is the largest power of X occurring in p(X) with a non-zero coefficient, with the convention that polynomial 0 has degree −∞. Hence, p(X)=∑i=0d​ai​Xi has degree d provided ad​=0. We let deg(p) denote the degree of a polynomial p and \PR{d} denote the set of polynomials over F of degree at most d.

Proposition 1. Let p(X) and q(X) be two polynomials in F[X]. Then ​deg(p+q)≤max{deg(p),deg(q)}deg(pq)=deg(p)deg(q).​

Given two non-zero polynomial a(X) and b(X), we say that b(X) divides a(X) or that b(X) is a factor of a(X) if there exists a polynomial q(X) such that a(X)=q(X)b(X). The set F[X] is a Euclidean domain, meaning one can perform euclidean division in F[X]: given two polynomials a(X) and b(X) with b(X)=0, there exists unique polynomials q(X) and r(X) such that a(X)=q(X)b(X)+r(X) and deg(r)<deg(b).

Roots

Given a polynomial p(X)=∑i​ai​Xi in F[X] and an element u∈F, the evaluation of p(X) at u, written p(u), is ∑i​ai​ui. The function from F to F mapping u to p(u) is called the polynomial function associated with p.1 We say that u is a root of p(X) if p(u)=0.

Theorem 1. Let p∈F[X] be a polynomial and u∈F be a field element. Then u is a root of p(X) if and only if X−u divides p(X). More generally, p(u)=v if and only if X−u divides p(X)−v.2

Proof. The if direction is straightforward. For the only if direction, note that since F[X] is Euclidean, there exists polynomials q and r such that p(X)=(X−u)q(X)+r(X) with deg(r)<deg(X−u)=1. Hence, the polynomial r must be a constant. Evaluating the polynomial equality at u, we obtain that r=p(u). Hence, if p(u)=v then p(X)−v=(X−u)q(X), which exactly means that X−u divides p(X)−v.

Theorem 2. Let p∈F[X] be a non-zero polynomial of degree d over F. Then p has at most d distinct roots in F.

Proof. By induction on d. The result clearly holds for d=0. Let d≥1 and assume that the result holds for degree 0,…,d−1. Let p∈F[x] be a polynomial of degree d. If p has no root then the result holds again. Otherwise, assume that p has a root u∈F. Then, by the previous theorem, p(X)=(X−u)q(X) for some polynomial q, where, by Proposition 1, q has degree d−1. If u′ is a root of p distinct from u, then (u′−u)q(u′)=0 which implies that q(u′)=0 since u′−u=0 and F is a field. Since q has at most d−1 distinct roots by the induction hypothesis, p has at most d distinct roots.

Lagrange Interpolation

In all the following, a set D={x0​,…,xd​} of distinct field elements xi​∈F will be called an evaluation domain (or simply domain) of size d+1.

Lagrange Interpolation Theorem. Let F be a finite field and let (xi​,yi​)0≤i≤d​∈F2 be d+1 pairs of field elements such that xi​=xj​ for i=j. Then there is a unique polynomial p(X)∈Fd(≤,)​[X] called the Lagrange interpolating polynomial, such that p(xi​)=yi​ for every i∈{0,…,d}.

Proof. Uniqueness is proved as follows: assume there exists two polynomials p(X) and q(X) interpolating the d+1 points. Then the polynomial p(X)−q(X) has d+1 roots but has degree at most d, hence must be the 0 polynomial, which implies that p(X)=q(X).

To establish existence, one introduces the Lagrange basis associated with the domain D={x0​,…,xd​}. This is the tuple of degree-d polynomials (ℓ0​(X),…,ℓd​(X)) defined as ℓj​(X):=0≤k≤dk=j​∏​xj​−xk​X−xk​​.

One can easily check that ℓj​(xi​)={01​if j=iif j=i.​

Then the Lagrange interpolating polynomial for (xi​,yi​)0≤i≤d​ is given by ℓ(X):=j=0∑d​yj​ℓj​(X). This polynomial has degree at most d and it is easy to see that ℓ(xi​)=yi​ for every i∈{0,…,d}.

Note that the Lagrange basis is indeed a basis for the F-vector space \PR{d} in the linear algebra sense. The coordinates of a polynomial p \in \PR{d} in this basis are (p(x0​),…,p(xd​)).

An important application of Lagrange interpolation is Shamir's secret sharing.

1

Over infinite fields, two polynomials are different if and only if the two corresponding polynomial functions are different. This is not the case over finite fields: for example, over F2​, the polynomial function x↦x2−x maps 0 and 1 to 0 yet polynomials X2−X and 0 are different.

2

This property will play an important role for the KZG polynomial commitment scheme.

Elliptic Curves

Contents

  • Generalities
  • Affine versus Projective Coordinates
    • Projective Plan
    • Elliptic Curves in Projective Coordinates

Generalities

Let F be a field of characteristic p>3.1 Let a,b∈F be two field elements such that 4a3+27b2=0. An elliptic curve in short Weierstrass form over F, denoted E(F), is the set of all pairs (x,y)∈F2 that satisfy the equation y2=x3+ax+b together with a distinguished element denoted O called the point at infinity: E(F)={(x,y)∈F2∣y2=x3+ax+b}∪{O}. This is the so-called affine representation of points of the elliptic curve. There is another family of representations called projective (more attractive from an algorithmic point of view) that we will discuss shortly.

Hasse's bound establishes that the number of points of E(F), called the order of E(F), is ∣E(F)∣=∣F∣+1−t where t is an integer (called the Frobenius trace or simply trace of the curve) satisfying ∣t∣≤2∣F∣​.

It is possible to equip E(F) with a commutative group law for which the point at infinity O is the identity element with the so-called chord-and-tangent rule. This group operation is denoted additively and called addition law. The inverse of a point (x,y)∈E(F)∖{O} is the point (x,−y).

From the addition law we can define scalar multiplication: for m∈Z and P∈E(F), the scalar multiplication of P by m, denoted [m]P or mP if there is no ambiguity, is given by [m]P:=⎩⎨⎧​Om timesP+⋯+P​​[−m](−P)​if m=0if m>0if m<0.​

The group structure of E(F) is either cyclic or "almost" cyclic. Namely, a general theorem establishes that E(F) has at most two invariant factors. In other words, E(F) is isomorphic to either the cyclic group Zn​ or a direct product of cyclic groups Zn1​​×Zn2​​ with n1​∣n2​.

Affine versus Projective Coordinates

Earlier we saw how to defined an elliptic curve using affine coordinates. This is not how elliptic curves are usually defined by mathematicians, who usually prefer to use projective geometry.

Projective Plan

Let F be a finite field of order q and let F∗:=F∖{0}. The projective plan over F, denoted P2(F), is the set of equivalence classes of F3∖{(0,0,0)} where two tuples (x,y,z) and (x′,y′,z′) are equivalent, denoted (x,y,z)∼(x′,y′,z′), if there is a scalar k∈F∗ such that (x′,y′,z′)=(kx,ky,kz). Such an equivalence class is called a projective point. A projective point contains q−1 tuples (x,y,z)∈F3. The convention is to denote projective points with capital letters and colon separators, i.e., (X:Y:Z) (or sometimes [X:Y:Z]) will denote the equivalence class {(kX,kY,kZ)∣k∈F∗}.

Equivalently, projective points can be seen as 1-dimensional subspaces ("lines") of the 3-dimensional vector space V=F3 over F. How many projective points are there? There are q3−1 non-zero vectors in F3, but each of the q−1 non-zero vectors in a subspace generates this subspace, hence the total number of 1-dimensional subspaces is q−1q3−1​=q2+q+1.

Another way to count the number of projective points is as follows:

  • there are q2 projective points of the form (X:Y:1), X,Y∈F;
  • there are q projective points of the form (1:Y:0), Y∈F;
  • there is one projective point of the form (0:1:0).

It is customary to identify the ordinary "affine" plane F2={(x,y)∣x,y∈F} with the first type of projective points, meaning there is an injective map from F2 to P2(F) given by (x,y)↦(x:y:1). The inverse of this map is (X:Y:Z)↦(X/Z,Y/Z).

The q+1 points of the second and third types (sharing the property that Z=0) are called "points at infinity" and form the so-called "line at infinity".

It is possible to define projective lines in a similar way to projective points: projective lines are 2-dimensional subspaces of F3 (with vector (0,0,0) removed). There are also q2+q+1 projective lines in P2(F), which is quite natural since any 1-dimensional subspace of F3 defines a unique 2-dimensional subspace via its orthogonal complement. A projective point "lies on" a projective line if it is included (in the set-theoretical sense) in the projective line. From this definition, it follows that (i) given any two projective points, there is exactly one projective line containing both of them, and (ii) given any two projective lines, there is exactly one projective point lying on both of them (meaning there are no parallel lines). Properties (i) and (ii) are in fact the axiomatic definition of a projective plan. Each projective line contains q2−1 vectors (x,y,z)∈F3∖{(0,0,0)}, and is the disjoint union of q+1 projective points. In particular, the q+1 projective points of the second and third type are indeed on the same projective line corresponding to the 2-dimensional subspace orthogonal to vector (0,0,1).

Elliptic Curves in Projective Coordinates

To obtain the equation defining an elliptic curve in projective coordinates, we substitute X/Z to x and Y/Z to y in the affine short Weierstrass equation y2=x3+ax+b(1) and multiply by Z3 to clear the denominators. This way, we obtain the projective short Weierstrass equation: Y2Z=X3+aXZ2+bZ3.(2)

It is easy to see that a projective point (X:Y:Z) with Z=0 satisfies (2) if and only if the corresponding affine point (x,y) with x=X/Z and y=Y/Z satisfies (1). Moreover, a projective point (X:Y:Z) on the line at infinity (Z=0) satisfies (2) if and only X=0, meaning the only of the q+1 projective points at infinity satisfying (2) is (0:1:0). This is the "curve point at infinity", the identity element of the group law, that we denoted O when we defined the elliptic curve in affine coordinates.

Hence, one of the main advantages of projective coordinates over affine ones is that it unifies ordinary points and the point at infinity O, which now has a projective representation as any other point, namely (0:1:0).

Another advantage is that computing the group law is more efficient because it does not require to perform modular division (which is only required to perform projective-to-affine conversion). A ballpark estimation is that a modular inversion is 20 to 100 times more costly than a modular multiplication depending on the platform and the implementation.

The projective coordinates obtained with the substitution x←X/Z, y←Y/Z is just one possibility among others, called homogeneous projective coordinates because the resulting projective equation (2) for the curve is homogeneous, meaning all terms have the same total degree, 3 here. An very common alternative are Jacobian coordinates defined by the substitution x←X/Z2,y←Y/Z3. The resulting projective equation is Y2=X3+aXZ4+bZ6. Projective points in Jacobian coordinates are defined by the equivalence relation (x,y,z)∼(x′,y,′,z′)if∃k∈F∗,(x′,y′,z′)=(k2x,k3y,kz). The point at infinity (Z=0) is the equivalence class (1:1:0)={(k2,k3,0):k∈F∗}.

See http://www.hyperelliptic.org/EFD/ for a list of various other possible coordinates systems.

1

It is possible to define elliptic curves over fields of characteristic 2 or 3 but equations are more complicated.

Pairings

Pairings have allowed a great number of new applications in cryptography. They were first used by Menezes, Okamoto, and Vanstone [MOV91] to break the discrete logarithm problem in supersingular elliptic curves (this is the so-called MOV attack). Later, they were used constructively by Joux [Jou00] to obtain a tripartite Diffie-Hellman protocol and by Boneh and Franklin [BF03] to obtain an identity-based encryption scheme. This got the three of them the Gödel prize in 2013.

We will start with the abstract definition of pairing groups and then we will see how to construct such groups from specific elliptic curves.

Contents

  • Abstract Definition
  • Further Resources

Abstract Definition

Let G1​, G2​, and Gt​ be three cyclic groups of prime order r. For reasons that will become clear later, we will denote G1​ and G2​ additively and Gt​ multiplicatively (in particular, G1​ and G2​'s identity elements are denoted 0 while Gt​'s identity element is denoted 1). A pairing is an efficiently computable function e:G1​×G2​→Gt​ which satisfies two properties:

  • non-degeneracy: P=0 and Q=0 implies e(P,Q)=1;
  • bilinearity: for every P1​,P2​∈G1​ and Q∈G2​ and for every P∈G1​ and Q1​,Q2​∈G2​, e(P1​+P2​,Q)e(P,Q1​+Q2​)​=e(P1​,Q)e(P2​,Q)=e(P,Q1​)e(P,Q2​).​

Note that bilinearity implies the (more useful in practice) property that for every P∈G1​, Q∈G2​, and a,b∈Zr​, e(aP,bQ)=e(P,Q)ab.

Non-degeneracy has many other definitions (all equivalent assuming bilinearity), such as:

  • e is not the constant function 1,
  • if G1​ and G2​ are generators of respectively G1​ and G2​, then e(G1​,G2​) is a generator of Gt​.

Constructing groups admitting a pairing is not very hard. For example, take G1​=G2​=Zr​ (the group of integers mod r equipped with addition), take for Gt​ any cyclic group of order r, let g be a generator of Gt​, and define e(x,y):=gxy.

However, for being useful from a cryptographic point of view, we need the discrete logarithm problem to be hard in the three groups G1​, G2​, and Gt​. (In the example above, while it may be hard in Gt​, it is certainly not in G1​ and G2​.) This is where elliptic curves come to the rescue.

Some more vocabulary: A pairing is said symmetric when G1​=G2​ and asymmetric when G1​=G2​. As we will see, both types can be constructed from elliptic curves. Historically, the first proposed constructions were symmetric, but nowadays the asymmetric type prevails for efficiency reasons. It is an open problem to construct a pairing such that G1​=G2​=Gt​=G and the discrete logarithm problem is (conjectured) hard in G.

Further Resources

  • Pairings for beginners by Craig Costello
  • Section 5.4 of the Moonmath manual
  • Martijn Maas' master thesis
  • this post about the security of pairing-friendly curves by Giacomo Pope
  • a post about BLS12-381 by Ben Edgington
  • a post about BN254 by Jonathan Wang.

Big-O Notation and Negligible Functions

In all the following, we consider functions from N to R+={x∈R∣x≥0} and we let λ denote the variable.

A function f is said to be negligible if f∈λ−ω(1) or equivalently if ∀k∈N,∃n∈N,∀λ≥n,f(λ)≤λ−c.

In words, f is negligible if it approaches zero faster than the inverse of any polynomial.

The set of all negligible functions is denoted negl. We often write f(λ)=negl(λ) in place of f∈negl.

Cryptographic Games

Game: Tentative Definition

A game consists of a main algorithm GAME and a (potentially empty) finite tuple of oracle algorithms O1​,…,On​. Then main algorithm (to which we simply refer as the game from here) takes as input 1λ where λ∈N is an integer called security parameter and runs in three phases:

  • initialization: the game initializes variables and generates some input inp;
  • attack: the game invokes an algorithm A called adversary on input inp; the adversary has oracle access to O1​,…,On​;
  • finalization: when the adversary halts and returns some output out, the game evaluates a predicate of out and all variables and returns the truth value of this predicate.

To make this definition rigorous, the programming language used to write the game should be completely specified. Here, we will content ourselves with specifying games in pseudocode.

A very simple game called ADD drawing two random λ-bit integers and returning true if the adversary successfully adds them would look like this:

Game ADD(1λ):​a,b←$​{2λ−1,…,2λ−1}c←A(a,b)return (c=a+b)​​

Notation and Conventions for Writing Games

  • Given a predicate A, we use assert A as a shorthand for if ¬A then return false
  • Games return true by default, meaning if the end of the game code is reached and the game has not returned yet, then it returns true. Finalization often consists in returning the truth vale of A∧B∧C∧⋯. Under this convention, the following finalization code return A∧B∧C is equivalent to ​assert Aassert Bassert C​

Advantage

For each security parameter λ, a game together with an adversary define a finite probability space specified by all random choices made by the game and the random coins of the adversary. This allows to define the probability of various events related to the execution of the game with a specific adversary.

In particular, given a game GAME and an adversary A, we write GAMEA(1λ)⇒b, or simply GAME⇒b when the context is clear, for the event that an execution of GAME with adversary A for security parameter λ returns b. When the game returns true we also say that the adversary "wins".

A game can be computational or decisional depending on how a quantity called advantage, measuring how well an adversary performs at winning the game, is defined.

The advantage of an adversary A against a game GAME is a function of the security parameter λ∈N∗ into [0,1] defined as AdvAgame​(λ):=Pr[GAME⇒true] if the game is computational and AdvAgame​(λ):=∣2Pr[GAME⇒true]−1∣ if the game is decisional. (We write the name of the game in small caps in the advantage superscript to lighten notation.)

We say that a game GAME is computationally hard if for every probabilistic polynomial-time (ppt) algorithm A, AdvAgame​(λ)=negl(λ). We say that a game GAME is statistically hard (or information-theoretically hard or unconditionally hard) if for every algorithm A (not necessarily polynomial-time), AdvAgame​(λ)=negl(λ). In the special case where the advantage of any algorithm is zero, one says that the game is perfectly hard (this is mostly used for commitment schemes that can be perfectly hiding or perfectly binding).

When we simply say that a game is hard, it usually means computationally hard (but this should always be clear from the context).

Hence, for a computationally, resp. statistically hard game, every ppt, resp. unbounded adversary "wins" with probability negligible close to 0 for a computational game and with probability negligibly close to 1/2 for a decisional game.

Reductions

Given two games X and Y, we say that X reduces to Y, denoted X≦Y, if there exists a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm B (called reduction) with access to an oracle such that for every algorithm A solving Y with non-negligible advantage, BA solves X with non-negligible advantage.

If X reduces to Y and Y reduces to X, we say that X and Y are equivalent, denoted X≡Y.

Proposition 1. Assume that X reduces to Y. Then X being hard implies Y being hard.

Proof. Contraposing, assume that Y is not hard, which by definition means that there exists a ppt algorithm A such that AdvAY​(λ)=negl(λ). Consider the reduction B from X to Y. Since A and B both run in polynomial time, BA runs in polynomial time as well. Moreover, by definition of a reduction, AdvBAX​(λ)=negl(λ). Hence, X is not hard.

Thus, X≦Y can be read as "X is not harder than Y" or Y is at least as hard as X".

In cryptography, we are constantly making assumptions of the form "X is hard". Proposition 1 can be used to compare the strength of various assumptions. Indeed, assuming we proved that X≦Y, then the assumption that X is hard implies that Y is hard too. If, in addition, there are some indications that Y≦X does not hold, then the assumption that X is hard is stronger than the assumption that Y is hard. Indeed, if X≦Y but Y≦X is not known to hold, then it might be that Y is hard yet X is easy.

For example, consider the discrete logarithm (DL) problem on one hand (given a group G and group elements G and X=xG, compute x) and the Computational Diffie-Hellman (CDH) problem on the other hand (given a group G and group elements G, X=xG, and Y, compute xY). One can easily prove that CDH ≦ DL (CDH reduces to DL) by constructing a reduction from CDH to DL: given an algorithm solving DL, one can solve CDH by first computing the discrete logarithm x of X and then computing xY. However, there is no proof that DL ≦ CDH (except in very specific situations). Hence, the assumption that CDH is hard is (for most groups) stronger than the assumption that DL is hard.

Another way Proposition 1 is often used in cryptography is for security proofs. Here, X is some hardness assumption such as DL and Y is a security game, say unforgeability (in the precise sense of EUF-CMA security in the random oracle model) of Schnorr signatures. Then, a security proof for Schnorr signatures consists in proving that X reduces to Y, i.e., the DL problem reduces to the EUF-CMA security of Schnorr signatures in the ROM. By Proposition 1, if DL is hard, then Schnorr signatures are EUF-CMA secure in the ROM.

Assumptions

Group Setup Algorithms

A standard group setup algorithm is an algorithm GroupSetup which on input the security parameter 1λ returns a pair (G,p) where p is a 2λ-bit prime and G is a cyclic group of order p.

A pairing group setup algorithm is an algorithm PairingSetup which on input the security parameter 1λ returns a tuple (G1​,G2​,Gt​,r,e) where r is a 2λ-bit prime, G1​, G2​, and Gt​ are cyclic groups of order r, and e:G1​×G2​→Gt​ is an efficiently computable pairing.

We adopt the convention that group/pairing setup algorithms do not return generators of the groups. They will be explicitly sampled in the games.

One usually distinguishes three types of pairing group setup algorithms [GPS08]:

  • a type-1 pairing group setup algorithm (also called symmetric pairing setup algorithm) is such that G1​=G2​;
  • a type-2 pairing group setup algorithm is such that G1​=G2​ and there exists an efficiently computable isomorphism ψ:G2​→G1​;
  • a type-3 pairing group setup algorithm is such that G1​=G2​ an no efficiently computable isomorphism ψ:G2​→G1​ is known.

Type-2 and type-3 pairing group setup algorithms are called asymmetric.

In all the following, we simply talk about "type-1/2/3 pairings" rather than "type-1/2/3 pairing group setup algorithms".

Assumptions in Standard Groups

Discrete Logarithm (DL)

  • interactive: no
  • falsifiable: yes

Computational Diffie-Hellman (CDH)

  • type: computational

  • falsifiable: yes
  • references:

  • type: decisional
  • interactive: no
  • falsifiable: yes
  • references:
  • notes: DDH ≦ CDH

Game DDH:​par←GroupSetup(1λ)(G,p)↞parb←$​{0,1}G←$​G∖{0}x←$​Zp​;X:=xGY←$​GZ0​:=xY;Z1​←$​Gb′←A(par,G,X,Y,Zb​)assert (b=b′)​​

q-Discrete Logarithm (q-DL)

Assumptions in Product Groups

The assumptions listed in this section are defined for a pair of groups (G1​,G2​) of equal order r. They are usually applied to groups returned by a pairing group setup algorithm PairingSetup but don't make use of the group Gt​ nor the pairing e. For this reason, we simply write (G1​,G2​,r)↞par when parsing the parameters par returned by PairingSetup.

(q1​,q2​)-co-Discrete Logarithm ((q1​,q2​)-co-DL)

  • type: computational
  • interactive: no
  • falsifiable: yes
  • references: [Che10, Lip10, FKL18, Rot22]
  • notes:

Game (q1​,q2​)-co-DL:​par←PairingSetup(1λ)(G1​,G2​,r)↞parG1​←$​G1​∖{0}G2​←$​G2​∖{0}x←$​Zr​x′←A(par,G1​,xG1​,…,xq1​G1​,G2​,xG2​,…,xq2​G2​)assert (x=x′)​​

Computational co-Diffie-Hellman (co-CDH)

  • type: computational
  • interactive: no
  • falsifiable: yes
  • references: [BLS04]
  • notes:
    • co-CDH ≦ DL in G2​
    • co-CDH ≡ CDH in G1​=G2​ for type-1 pairings
    • co-CDH ≦ CDH in G1​ for type-2 pairings (see BLS Signatures, Proposition)

Game co-CDH:​par←PairingSetup(1λ)(G1​,G2​,r)↞parG2​←$​G2​∖{0}x←$​Zr​;X:=xG2​Y←$​G1​Z←A(par,G2​,X,Y)assert (Z=xY)​​

Computational co-Diffie-Hellman* (co-CDH*)

  • type: computational
  • interactive: no
  • falsifiable: yes
  • references: [CHKM10]
  • notes:
    • sometimes simply called (confusingly) co-CDH (e.g. [BDN18])
    • co-CDH∗ ≦ CDH in G1​
    • co-CDH∗ ≦ DL in G2​
    • co-CDH∗ ≦ co-CDH
    • co-CDH∗ ≡ CDH in G1​=G2​ for type-1 pairings (see BLS Signatures, Proposition)
    • co-CDH∗ ≡ co-CDH for type-2 pairings (see BLS Signatures, Proposition)

Game co-CDH∗:​par←PairingSetup(1λ)(G1​,G2​,r)↞parG1​←$​G1​∖{0}G2​←$​G2​∖{0}x←$​Zr​;X1​:=xG1​;X2​:=xG2​Y←$​G1​Z←A(par,G1​,X1​,G2​,X2​,Y)assert (Z=xY)​​

Computational ψ-co-Diffie-Hellman (ψ-co-CDH)

  • type: computational
  • interactive: yes
  • falsifiable: no (for type-3 pairings)
  • references: [SV07, BDN18]
  • notes:
    • ψ-co-CDH ≦ CDH in G1​
    • ψ-co-CDH ≦ DL in G2​
    • ψ-co-CDH ≦ co-CDH∗ ≦ co-CDH
    • ψ-co-CDH ≡ co-CDH for type-2 pairings (the isomorphism ψ enables to compute SolveCoCDH(U) efficiently as ψ(U), assuming ψ(G2​)=G1​)

Game ψ-co-CDH:​par←PairingSetup(1λ)(G1​,G2​,r)↞parG1​←$​G1​∖{0}G2​←$​G2​∖{0}x←$​Zr​;X1​:=xG1​;X2​:=xG2​Y←$​G1​Z←ASolveCoCDH(par,G1​,X1​,G2​,X2​,Y)assert (Z=xY)​Oracle SolveCoCDH(U):​//solves co-CDH for (G2​,U,G1​)assert U∈G2​for u∈Zr​ doif uG2​=U thenreturn uG1​​​

(q1​,q2​)-Strong Diffie-Hellman ((q1​,q2​)-SDH)

  • type: computational
  • interactive: no
  • falsifiable: yes
  • references: [BB08]
  • notes:
    • (q,1)-SDH usually called q-SDH
    • not to be confused with another assumption named SDH introduced in [ABR01]
    • (q1​+1,q2​)-SDH ≦ (q1​,q2​)-SDH
    • (q1​,q2​+1)-SDH ≦ (q1​,q2​)-SDH
